ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: different ways the brain is activated during social settings and behaviors that go with it

This course allowed me to explore the vast social realm of neuroscience, based on neural mechanisms and functions of the brain. I was able to learn about human tendencies, specifically though moral outrage, trust, and cooperation.
I learned a lot about social neuroscience, such as prosocial concern, theory of mind, vicarious reward, and more.

Learned so much about how the brain encodes various social interactions and dynamics such as trust, cooperation, rejection, empathy, altruism, etc. Went into detail about brain structures and functions, which was interesting to map on to more abstract social concepts.

Taking this course allowed me to apply my existing neuroscience knowledge to fascinating concepts of human interaction and sociality. In addition to exploring countless research papers and studies, our class was able to form new hypotheses, discuss our curiosities, and apply our knowledge to facets of everyday life (particularly social media and its neurological effects). This course both galvanized and expanded by neuroscience knowledge, and I possess a stronger understanding of the fascinating, hidden processes that govern our everyday interactions.

I learned about the neural underpinnings of various social mechanisms we engage with every day, such as altruism, moral decision-making, relationship-formation, and impression-formation based on just seeing someone else's face.
An understanding of what is happening on a neurobiological level as our brains participate in various social tasks.
I learned about various topics within social neuroscience, which built upon my social psychology knowledge.
Knowledge of brain mechanisms involved in social behavior
-Intro to the social brain
I learned about the social brain and learned about a broad range of studies on relationships, compassion, altruism, empathy, and prejudice.
I developed my skills of reading/interpreting scientific literature.
Reading and assessing research papers and learning more about neuroscience through the lens of social psychology
Insights into the brain processes associated with social behavior
Social neuroscience
A more in-depth understanding of what areas of the brain are implicated in social situations and interactions.
Knowledge of neural mechanisms of social interactions, scientific paper reading and scientific writing
This was a delightful course that delved into many facets of social neuroscience, with some of the most interesting topics including empathy, punishment, social influence.

We learned a lot about the neural processes behind different types of interactions and social phenomena. The paper was an interesting way to engage with the material in the context of social media apps.
I learned a lot about the brain relevant to social neuroscience and practical skills like reading scientific literature.
I learned a lot about the social mechanisms of the evolved human brain, as well as how to apply and analyze the weaknesses and strenghts of different neuroimaging methods used in social neuroscience.
I learned a lot about the social brain and the neuroscience behind the formation social interactions, perceptions and relationships.

I learned a lot about the intersection of psychology and neuroscience. Often psychology courses are very theoretical and the studies address issues in an abstract and academic way and often in neuroscience the content is very scientific and biological. With this course I felt that the material was very grounded in every day interactions and helped me learn a lot about not only how but why humans interact with other humans the way that they do.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found no weaknesses with this course, rather I thoroughly enjoyed all of the material and the way in which it was taught by Dr. Crockett. This course does a fantastic job of presenting interesting facts and ideas regarding neuroscience which allows its students to engage with the material in new and exciting ways which are both intellectually challenging and thought-provoking.
Virtual lectures were good, but it was hard to stay engaged over Zoom

Great course! One strength was that we covered a wide variety of social interactions/dynamics-- both positive and negative-- so we weren't too narrowed in on one topic. Not many weaknesses to speak of!

This course was exceptional in a multitude of ways, including its organization, breadth, depth, relevance of content, applicability to modern society, student involvement, and academic rigor. The papers on the syllabus were intriguing and well-selected, and the course assignments and assessments accurately reflected what we learned in class. I find it difficult to point out any glaring weaknesses; this was one of the best classes I have taken at Yale.

The material in this class is already pretty interesting as-is because of its relevance to our every day lives, but Prof Crockett did an excellent job of making it even more interesting by embedding video clips within lessons that demonstrated the phenomena we were studying, whether through a ted talk or through a social experiment. Prof Crockett was also very accommodating of extenuating circumstances while making sure that the rigor of class was still up to par with Yale standards. The only weakness I can think of is that the lectures can be a bit dry because there is sometimes minimal interaction, but I also appreciated that Prof Crockett gave everyone opportunities to participate by asking people to respond in the chat but didn't force anyone to participate if they didn't want to.

The professor and TA team were very well organized and very knowledgeable on the content they were presenting! Each class, Prof Crockett provided us with a "pop quiz" that was ungraded but was REALLY helpful with gauging how well we were understanding the material. I only wish I could have taken this course in person! I am sure that my engagement would have been even higher then.
Lectures were great; I liked the quizzes at the beginning of each class. Our professor always answered our questions.
Loved Prof Crockett and the TAs!!  Genuinely kind.  Might have liked a bit more guidance bc I did feel lost at times but their compassion for the class meant a lot.

Dr. Crockett had us do breakout room discussions at the start of class, which were fantastic. At time it felt like we were learning just associations between brain regions and behavior, though (and less about why activity in these regions is important)
-The lecture material was very intersting
Strengths were definitely the material itself! The social brain is fascinating!
Strengths was professor (so nice and understanding, super receptive to comments and questions). Weakness was lack of feedback for any and all assignments (prior to the due date).
Dr.Crockett is SUCH a kind person and wonderful lecturer. She is so knowledgeable and knows how to translate that into effective lectures.

Molly Crockett was a great professor and clearly very knowledgeable about this subject. She made the lectures engaging and the TF's were also fantastic. The primary weaknesses had more to do with the virtual nature of the course than anything else.

Strengths - very interesting lecture and very cool use of sections by focusing on a topic and allowing discussion
Weaknesses - not very clear instructions for writing assignments, more examples would have been helpful

Only strengths come to mind -- the material was so interesting, I felt like every lecture was a TED talk and I would rewatch them for fun. Exams and grading were incredibly fair, if not generous. Not to state the obvious, but it could only be improved if it were in person.

Strengths: The final exam was made optional which was significant as it lifted off a burden for a lot of students. There was also time in the beginning of lecture where we reviewed material from last lecture that was very helpful.

The strength of this course is the lecture content and reading material - Professor Crockett organizes the class wonderfully so that concepts build on each other as the semester progresses. At some points however, I did feel that the class went too quickly.

Strengths: the material was fascinating, Prof. Crockett and the TF's were all incredibly supportive and kind, and the class was structured at a really great pace.

Weaknesses: I didn't really enjoy the breakout rooms in the beginning of every class... sometimes most people would keep their cameras and microphones off for the whole time and it would get a little bit awkward.

The course was great! I really don't have many constructive things to say. My engagement was a medium not because of Professor Crockett or the course material but because of the nature of spring semester and zoom learning. I was just so tired and defeated from the past year that by the end of the semester I couldn't find the energy to attend lecture live and just watched the recordings. The lectures themselves were structured very well! Occasionally I felt that a study was introduced and explained too quickly but for the most part I really enjoyed lecture and Professor Crockett's teaching style.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Crockett was super accommodating to any issues students had, which made me feel supported throughout the semester
Prof crockett was super understanding and kind during the pandemic
Professor was very accommodating and helpful which helped with remote learning.

Dr. Crockett did a fantastic job of adapting this course to COVID-19 circumstances, as more media and video presentations were shown in lectures through online tools, and this allowed for full engagement from the class. Breakout rooms at the start of the lecture allowed for students to take a mini quiz with their peers and test their knowledge of the previous lecture's content and create a more social and collaborative learning environment even on zoom.
Having the breakout room with a group discussion of questions at the beginning of every lecture was nice, but sometimes stressful.

The course maintained a synchronous format. This was crucial. Students were able to ask questions in real time, and we were often able to engage in new and exciting conversations that would not have occurred asynchronously. The exams were also well-adapted; they were both open-note and open for roughly a week, and the questions tested our ability to apply our knowledge rather than to memorize it.

Excellent use of breakout rooms -- we had mini quizzes at the beginning of every lecture that were ungraded. These provided good opportunities to talk with other students and to engage with the material beyond lectures. Prof Crockett also made great use of the chat to test our understanding, and great use of multimedia presentations.
The use of breakout rooms to take the quizzes was actually very helpful!
Professor Crockett was very accommodating throughout the semester. The use of breakout rooms was also great.
The instructor was very understanding of the mental taxation of distance learning and was very accommodating!
Professor Crockett was very flexible and I really appreciated the final being optional during a stressful finals period
-none
Breakout rooms were a great way to parse through and review the material!
I liked how section wasn't every week but we still had section. That way it was engaging but not overwhelming.
Professor was so flexible.
Breakout rooms werent super useful.

The quizzes in breakout rooms at the beginning of class were helpful, as well as the 3x/semester virtual sections. They focused on different areas of neuroscience research, including academic writing and replication.
Live recorded lectures and live section were very helpful and worked with the class size.

This was bar none the BEST course to take in this trying semester. My personal life was in shambles this semester, as were many of my peers', and Prof Crockett clearly took our struggles to heart and adapted the demands of the course to help improve the wellbeing of her students. No other Professor demonstrated this level of care and compassion. She even made the final optional -- waving a magic wand for all of us that cared about the class deeply, but were struggling to make it through the semester. Exemplary professor and human being. I am her biggest fan.
Making the final exam optional really helped me during this pandemic as well as having certain days be class catch up time.
I think the online lecture format worked fine, though maybe the breakout rooms didn't always encourage student discusison.
Everything went really well. Prof. Crockett was incredibly kind, supportive and accommodating throughout the course and the TF's were also super understanding and helpful!
I appreciated that the lectures were recorded!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! Very interesting, but need previous knowledge of the brain to grasp.
yes! very interesting topics and great professor
Yes, great introduction to social neuroscience. Light workload and great professor.

Yes! Personally, I believe anyone and everyone should take this course, as it does a wonderful job of explaining why humans are the way we are. It gives both an introspective and retrospective view of the world in which we live, and it allows its students to fully grasp the material for which they are being taught while also allowing for questions that transcend the material through speculation from accumulated knowledge within the course. I thoroughly enjoyed it and will be recommending it to all of my friends and peers.
Yes, if you're interested in social neuroscience, neuroscience methods, etc.
Absolutely! I think Crockett said she was leaving, however, so that is a bummer.. BUT, I still think the content of the class itself is very stimulating and interesting, so I would recommend.

I would recommend this course to another studenthands down. Whether students are interested in neuroscience, psychology, sociology, or pure human interaction (which is inherently applicable to life itself), this course provides an excellent intellectual experience. The topics are both interesting and relevant, the studies are fresh and well-designed, and the final paper (which has students analyze a social media app from a social neuroscience perspective) is genuinely fun to work through. A wonderful course.

Yes. Social neuroscience is fascinating! Even as someone who is not very STEM, I found the neuroscience parts to be quite interesting because I could always connect what I learned with my personal experiences.

Yes! I took this as a psych major after taking The Human Brain, and while it was a challenge, it was a great course. I learned a lot more about the neural mechanisms underlying several psych processes which were very interesting!
I would recommend, but only for people who are interested in and prepared for an advanced neuroscience course.
Absolutely
Yes!!

Absolutely. The material and teaching were fantastic. If you know a little about social neuro, there is a lot of review (e.g. prisoner's dilemmas, the brain's rewards system), but later in the class there is cutting edge material.
Absoultely. A great way to learn about the social brain while being free of stress
Yes! The material is fascinating and Prof. Crockett is an incredibly kind and intelligent instructor!
Absolutely! It was engaging but didn't have an overwhelming and unnecessary workload.
Yes if they needed to fulfill their Neuroscience major requirement
Yes.
Yes! I really enjoyed this class.
Yes! It is a great introduction to social neuroscience, somewhat close to a surgery course, so many topics are covered.
YES! Most interesting material I've ever encountered and I simply have too many good things to say about Professor Crockett. Regardless of your major, take this course!
Yes. I learned a lot about different neural processes in social neuroscience even though it's a relatively new field.

Absolutely, Professor Crockett is very clearly extremely knowledgeable but also relays that well during lecture and in office hours. She always takes time to answer questions and makes us reflect on the material.
I would recommend this course to another student, but at times the information load can be a lot!
Absolutely!!!! The content is so so so interesting and Prof. Crockett is absolutely brilliant.

I would! I can't speak to its rigor during an in person semester but I found that it wasn't too much work and I really enjoyed the course material. The perfect course for psychology majors on the neuro track:)

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: occasional virtual sections
NA
Three additional live, virtual sections were held throughout the semester.
The lectures were also recorded but I usually tried to attend class when I could.
live virtual lecture
Occasionally I would watch the recorded lectures instead.
We had 3 virtual seminar sections
3 virtual discussion sections throughout the semester
Sometimes watched asynchronously
-discussion section
There were three virtual discussion sections throughout the course
we had three discussion sections lead by TFs, and Prof. Crockett recorded all the lectures
Live virtual lectures that were recorded. Love virtual sections.
live section participations.
Both a live virtual lecture and recorded.
3 live sections (not recorded)
There was live virtual lecture but it was always recorded. There was also three discussion sections through the year.
virtual discussion section
There were 3 sections led by the TFs over Zoom throughout the semester.
The lectures were live but were recorded so people had the option to go back and rewatch.
